newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Northam strike likely to be averted - union.
newsitem.headline: Northam strike likely to be averted - union.

text.p: The National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) said on Wednesday that workers at Northam Platinum Ltd were debating management's latest wage offer and a planned strike at the mine was likely to be averted.
NUM regional coordinator Mahlakeng Mahlakeng told Reuters workers were due to discuss Northam management's latest revised wage offer at a meeting on Thursday.
"The workers will be having a further meeting tomorrow and see what they can make of management's further offer," Mahlakeng said. He said chances of the workers going on strike were slim.
"The possibility of strike action at the moment is very slim. It is a very, very small hiccup but a final decision has to be taken by workers tomorrow," he added.
The majority of Northam's 3,300 union members voted to strike last week after management and the union reached deadlock over wages on September 26.
The union had initially demanded a 15 percent pay hike but was prepared to accept management's offer of 10 percent.
NUM said the point of contention was wage parity, as Northam's minimum wage of around 556 rand was well below that of other mines.
Northam produced 75,365 ounces of precious metals in concentrates in the three months to September.
The mine recorded a net loss before capital spending of 7.39 million rand in the September quarter after turning in a profit of 8.17 million in the previous quarter.
